history.content:
Ideally, you might want to take all of them before 189. If your major concern is the workload, I think the workload is fine, but it largely depends what your background is. For your reference, personally, 170 takes less time than 70 and 126 takes about the same time as 70. I haven't taken 127 and 61c, but I've heard from my friends who're taking them that 127 has a lighter workload than 126, while 61c takes more time than 126, 127, and 170. 

However, I think probably the best thing to do is staying in all three for a week to see whether you're okay with the workload; drop one and take it with 189 if the workload is too heavy. 

------------

Second opinion: if you are taking 61C and 70 as a freshman you can probably handle it. 126 and 127 are medium/low workload, and 170 is hard but there is some overlap with 61B. However, I would caution that EE16A/16B are pretty high workload, esp. with labs.

------------

Third opinion- don't attempt this unless you are a) confident in your existing mathematical capabilities and b) are willing to spend most of your waking hours on problem sets.

For the record, I'm currently taking 61C, 126 and 127 with a decent helping of extracurriculars. Loved and did great on 70's probability, took 170 last semester and did well, had 16B and Math 110 under my belt for linear algebra knowledge (which really really helps for the first 3 or 4 weeks of 127). 

In short, it is an extremely painful schedule. Usually I'm able to finish the problem sets each week but it's tight every week. Also I feel I've not gained as much from 126 and 127 as I thought I would because there's simply no time to idly think about the concepts that they teach (which are far more complex than whatever you've seen in the lower division). I do a problem set, move onto the next assignment from the next class, and put off that class for the rest of a week. 

As someone who also wanted to take these classes to get into machine learning, I feel like overworking and jamming everything in at once defeats the whole point of taking the classes in the first place. Prof. Sahai says these classes are supposed to build intuition for ML, but the way to build intuition is not to be furiously LaTeX-ing up a homework 6 hours before its due, having rushed or half-assed all the problems. If you really want to build intuition, it's probably worth it to pick 2 of the 3, take a lighter schedule, and really savor the material (I certainly wish I did).

------------

If you have not taken 16A/B would recommend taking those before 127 (you have to take them anyways), 70 should prepare you well for 126. If you plan on taking 16A and 16B in the same semester, I would limit it to 2 of the above 3 tops and even that would be kind of pushing it since you would be taking 4 techs.

Ideally, you might want to take all of them before 189. If your major concern is the workload, I think the workload is fine, but it largely depends what your background is. For your reference, personally, 170 takes less time than 70 and 126 takes about the same time as 70. I am wondering whether its feasible to take the above courses during the fall. I may also be doing EE16A/EE16B bc its a lower division requirement. Some background: I am an intended CS major currently in my sophomore year at Cal. I am currently taking 70, 61C, and a decal in app development whose workload is basically equivalent to a moderate tech. I want to get into ML in the spring and Prof. Sahai has suggested that 126, 127 will really round up my knowledge of ML. Is taking these three techs the right way to go in the fall then, or should I take one concurrently (maybe EE127) with ML during the spring?
history.subject: EE126, EE127 & CS170 during the fall
